case_name: Surendra Nath Bibra v. Stephen Court Limited

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 661 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 661 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 17, 1959 of Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 274 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1959 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 274 of 1958.

facts.text: Application under s. 115 CPC and art. 227 Constitution filed by tenant Shri Surendra Nath Bibra in Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Calcutta in an application under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and under art. 227 of the Constitution filed by the tenant, Shri Surendra Nath Bibra,

facts.text: Stephen Court Limited is the plaintiff and respondent.

anchor.surface_text: number appellant before us. Stephen Court Limited, respondent before us, hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff,

facts.text: Plaintiff filed suit in Court of Small Causes, Calcutta for recovery of rent from September 1956 to November 1956 at Rs. 350 per month and interest against defendant.

anchor.surface_text: filed a suit in the Court of Small Causes, Calcutta, for the recovery of rent from September 1956 to November,1956, at the rate of Rs. 350/- per mensem, and interest, against the appellant, hereinafter referred to as the defendant,

facts.text: Defendant was monthly tenant by virtue of lease dated April 30, 1956 for flat No. 17 at 18A Park Street, Stephen Court, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that the defendant was a monthly tenant by virtue of a lease dated April 30, 1956, under the plaintiff, in respect of flat No. 17 at promises No. 18A, Park Street, known as Stephen Court in the town of Calcutta,

facts.text: Lease was for 21 years.

anchor.surface_text: he executed a lease on April 30, 1956, for a period of 21 years,

facts.text: Defendant relied on plaintiff's representation that three bed-rooms and two bath rooms would be available in flat No. 17.

anchor.surface_text: Pleaed that relying on the representation and assurance of the plaintiff that three bed-rooms, two bath rooms etc. would be available to the defendant in flat No. 17

facts.text: Plaintiff put defendant in possession only of two bed-rooms, not three.

anchor.surface_text: but the plaintiff put him in possession only of two bed-rooms and number three,

facts.text: Small Causes Court Judge Mr. Mandal found defendant not put into possession of one of the three bed-rooms.

anchor.surface_text: The Small Cause Court Judge, Mr. Mandal, found that the defendant had number been put into possession of one of the three bed-rooms.

facts.text: Small Causes Judge held defendant entitled to suspend payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: Purporting to follow Katyayani Debi v. Udoy Kumar Das  1  and Abhoya Charan Sen v. Hem Chandra Pal  2  he held that the defendant was entitled to suspend payment- of rent to the plaintiff.

facts.text: Plaintiff preferred application under s. 38 Presidency Small Cause Courts Act against dismissal of suit.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff then preferred an application under s. 38 of the Presidency Small Cause Courts Act against the dismissal of its suit.

facts.text: Full Bench of Small Causes Court held plaintiff's claim for arrears succeeds despite failure to give possession of one bedroom.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench of the Small Causes Court, following Ram Lal Dutt Sarkar v. Dhirendra Nath.Roy, 3  held that the plaintiffs claim for arrears of rent must succeed in spite of the fact that the landlord had failed to give possession of one out of the three bed-rooms

facts.text: Full Bench decreed the suit but noted tenant not debarred from other reliefs like apportionment or damages.

anchor.surface_text: of the demised premises. The Bench, however, made it clear that the number- applicability of the principle of suspension of rent in the present suit for recovery of arrears of rent for a parti- cular period will number necessarily debar the tenant from claiming other appropriate reliefs against the failure of the landlord to put him In possession of the entire demised premises by way of apportionment of rent or damages. Accordingly, it decreed the suit.

facts.text: Defendant filed application under s.115 CPC and art.227 in High Court praying dismissal of suit or proportionate rent.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant then filed an application under s. 115, Civil Procedure Code, and art. 227 of the Constitution. In the application the defendant prayed that the suit be dismissed. In the alternative, the defendant alleged that the plaintiff was at best entitled only to a proportionate rent.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the application

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: and the defendant having obtained special leave, the matter is number before us.

facts.text: Defendant contends doctrine of suspension of rent applies as plaintiff deliberately did not give possession of one bedroom.

anchor.surface_text: He says that the doctrine of suspension of rent should be applied to the facts of this case because the plaintiff had deliberately number given possession  1  30 C.W.N.  P.C.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds tenant not entitled to suspend rent but must pay proportionate rent.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case we are of the opinion that the tenant is number entitled to suspend the payment of rent but he must pay a proportionate part of the rent.

facts.text: Defendant paid rent voluntarily for four months, but three months was advance security deposit.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarjoo Prasad, the learned companynsel for the plaintiff, urges that the defendant had paid rent voluntarily for four months--this fact also is relied on by the High Court-and therefore we should number remand the case. But we find that three months rent was paid in advance as security deposit,

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside orders of High Court, Full Bench and Small Causes Judge, remands to Small Causes Court for disposal in light of judgment on apportionment.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal succeeds. We set aside the orders of the- High Court and of the Full Bench of the Small Causes Court and of the Judge Small Causes Court, and remand the case to the Court of Small Causes, Calcutta, with the direction that it will dispose of the suit in the light of this judgment. The parties would be at liberty to lead evidence before the Court of Small Causes on the question of apportionment of rent.

facts.text: High Court rejected apportionment as no specific plea in written statement and no prayer to amend.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the plea of apportionment of rent on the ground that the defendant had number taken a specific plea to this effect in the written statement. The second ground given by the High Court was that it would be unreasonable to thrust a relief on the defendant unless he himself chooses one or more of the alternative reliefs available to him. Further, numberprayer was 3 made before the High Court to amend the written statement to include this relief.

It is numberdoubt true that the Privy Council was companycerned with an agricultural tenancy but the Privy Council decided the appeal on a matter of principle, the principle being that the doctrine enunciated, in Neak v. Mackenzie  2   should number be regarded as a rule of justice, equity and good companyscience in India in all circumstances.

Be that as it may, in our opinion, the doctrine laid down in Neale v. Mackengie  2  is too inflexible and cannot be applied to all cases.

holdings.text: the doctrine laid down in Neale v. Mackengie is too inflexible and cannot be applied to all cases. As observed by Sir George Rankin, the doctrine cannot be justified as a dependable rule to be adhered to notwithstanding hard cases.

anchor.surface_text: It is interesting to numbere that the subject-matter of the lease in Neak v. Mackenzie  2  was a dwelling house and land attached to it, and it was eight acres of the land which was attached to the house that the tenant had been kept out ,of possession. Be that as it may, in our opinion, the doctrine laid down in Neale v. Mackengie  2  is too inflexible and cannot be applied to all cases. As observed by Sir George Rankin, the ,doctrine cannot be justified as a dependable rule to be adhered to numberwithstanding hard cases.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes rigid English precedent; observes inequities in both full suspension and full payment; holds application must depend on case circumstances balancing equities.

holdings.text: it will depend on the circumstances of each case, whether a tenant would be entitled to suspend payment of the rent or whether he should be held liable to pay proportionate part of the rent.

anchor.surface_text: On the one hand it does number seem ,equitable that when a tenant enjoys a substantial portion of the property of the landlord, leased to him, without much inconvenience, he should number pay any companypensation for the use of the property , in other words, to borrow the language of Sir George Ranking that he should enjoy a windfall. On the other hand it is unfair that if a tenant is number given possession of a substantial portion of the property, he should be asked to pay any companypensation for the use of the property while he is taking appropriate measures for specific performance of the companytract. It seems to us that it will depend on the circumstances of each case, whether a tenant would be entitled to suspend payment of the rent or whether he should be held liable to pay proportionate part of the rent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equitable balancing of windfall to tenant vs overpayment; rejects one-size-fits-all; case-by-case determination.

holdings.text: On the facts of this case we are of the opinion that the tenant is not entitled to suspend the payment of rent but he must pay a proportionate part of the rent.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case we are of the opinion that the tenant is number entitled to suspend the payment of rent but he must pay a proportionate part of the rent. We may make it clear that like the Privy Council in Ram Lal Dutts  1  case we are number deciding that the doctrine of suspension ,of rent should or should number be applied at all to cases of eviction ,of the lessee by the lessor from a part of the land, and if so, whether it is limited to rents reserved as a lump sum, and whether it is a rigid or discretionary rule-these questions will call for careful review when they are presented by the facts of a particular case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies flexible doctrine to facts: tenant enjoyed substantial portion (two of three bedrooms); proportionate liability equitable.

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with Mr. Chatterjee that the decision of the Privy Council in Ram Lal Dutts case can be distinguished on the ground urged by him. It is undoubtedly true that the Privy Council was concerned with an agricultural tenancy but the Privy Council decided the appeal on a matter of principle, the principle being that the doctrine enunciated in Neale v. Mackenzie should be regarded as a rule of justice, equity and good conscience in India in all circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with Mr. Chatterjee that the decision of the Privy Council in Ram Lal Dutts  1  case can be distinguished on the ground urged by him. Mackenzie  2   should number be regarded as a rule of justice, equity and good companyscience in India in all circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects distinction based on agricultural tenancy; Privy Council laid general principle applicable broadly.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the Full Bench of the Small Causes Court should have remanded the case for calculation of the proportionate rent for the portion of the premises taken possession of by the defendant. It would be inequitable to allow the plaintiff to recover the full rent when he has not delivered possession of the whole of the premises in question.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case we are of the opinion that the tenant is number entitled to suspend the payment of rent but he must pay a proportionate part of the rent. We may make it clear that like the Privy Council in Ram Lal Dutts  1  case we are number deciding that the doctrine of suspension ,of rent should or should number be applied at all to cases of eviction ,of the lessee by the lessor from a part of the land, and if so, whether it is limited to rents reserved as a lump sum, and whether it is a rigid or discretionary rule-these questions will call for careful review when they are presented by the facts of a particular case.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Full Bench of the Small Causes Court should have remanded the case for calculation of the proportionate rent for the portion of the premises taken possession of by the defendant. In our view, the High Court has taken too technical a view. It would be inequitable to allow the plaintiff to recover the full rent when he has number delivered possession of the whole of the premises in question.

In the result the appeal succeeds. We set aside the orders of the- High Court and of the Full Bench of the Small Causes Court and of the Judge Small Causes Court, and remand the case to the Court of Small Causes, Calcutta, with the direction that it will dispose of the suit in the light
